Article.ArticleTitle: Removal of toluene using ozone at room temperature over mesoporous Mn/Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> catalysts.

AbstractText: The catalytic oxidation of toluene with ozone at room temperature was carried out over hierarchically ordered mesoporous catalysts (CeO<sub>2</sub> (meso), Mn<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> (meso), ZrO<sub>2</sub> (meso), and γ-Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> (meso)) and Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> with various textural properties and phases (γ-Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> (meso), γ-Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> (13 nm), and α-Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>) to examine the effects of the nature of the catalyst on the catalytic activity. The catalysts were characterized by N<sub>2</sub>-physisorption measurements, powder X-ray diffraction, temperature programmed reduction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and scanning transmission electron microscopy with energy dispersive spectroscopy. Among the ordered mesoporous catalysts, γ-Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> (meso) had the highest toluene removal efficiency because of its highest surface area and pore volume, which in turn was selected for further investigation. Manganese (Mn) was introduced to various Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> to improve the toluene removal efficiency. Comparing the Mn-loaded catalysts supported on various Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> with different crystalline phases or pore structures, Mn/γ-Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> (meso), had the highest catalytic activity as well as the highest CO<sub>2</sub>/CO ratio. The higher activity was attributed to the larger surface area, weaker interaction between Mn and Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>, and larger portion of Mn<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> phase. The increase in ozone concentration led to an improvement in the carbon balance but this enhancement was insufficient due to the deposition of by-products on the catalyst. After long term tests at room temperature, the reaction intermediates and carbonaceous deposits of the used catalysts were identified.
